item.description:
## Overview
The Suppliers resource is the core of the SRM (Supplier Relationship Management) functionality in Invent-MAG, managing all supplier information, relationships, and procurement interactions. This centralizes supplier data for purchasing, quality management, and analytics purposes.

## Purpose
Suppliers represent organizations or individuals that provide products or services to the business. This resource maintains comprehensive supplier profiles including contact information, transaction history, performance metrics, and relationship status, enabling effective procurement and supplier management.

## Key Functionality
- Manage complete supplier profiles and contact information
- Track supplier lifecycle from prospect to preferred supplier
- Maintain supplier segmentation and categorization
- Store multiple contact persons and addresses
- Track supplier payment terms and credit limits
- Monitor supplier performance and ratings
- Support supplier hierarchies (parent-child relationships)
- Enable supplier-specific pricing and terms
- Track supplier certifications and compliance

## Common Operations
- **GET /suppliers** - List all suppliers with search, filtering, and pagination
- **GET /suppliers/{id}** - Retrieve detailed supplier profile and history
- **POST /suppliers** - Create new supplier records
- **PUT/PATCH /suppliers/{id}** - Update supplier information, status, or ratings
- **DELETE /suppliers/{id}** - Remove supplier records (with data retention policies)

## Relationships
- **Supplier Interactions**: Complete communication history
- **Purchase Orders**: All procurement transactions
- **Purchase Order Items**: Detailed purchase history by product
- **Payments**: Payment history and outstanding balances
- **Products**: Products sourced from suppliers
- **Transactions**: Financial transaction records
- **Accounts**: Supplier account balances and payable status
- **Warehouses**: Delivery locations for received goods

## Important Fields
- Supplier name and company information
- Contact details (email, phone, fax)
- Billing and shipping addresses
- Supplier type (manufacturer, distributor, service provider)
- Tax identification numbers
- Payment terms and credit limit
- Supplier status (active, inactive, blocked, preferred)
- Assigned procurement contact
- Supplier category or classification
- Performance rating
- Preferred currency and language
- Lead time and minimum order quantities
- Certifications and compliance documents
- Custom fields for business-specific data

## Business Context
Use these endpoints when:
- Onboarding new suppliers
- Processing purchase orders
- Managing supplier inquiries and issues
- Analyzing supplier performance
- Segmenting suppliers for strategic sourcing
- Reviewing supplier payment status
- Generating supplier reports and scorecards
- Maintaining SRM data quality
- Integrating with procurement systems
- Supporting procurement team with supplier insights
- Managing supplier contracts and agreements
- Conducting supplier audits and evaluations

item.name: Taxes

query.description: The number of taxes to return per page. Defaults to 15.

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves a paginated list of all tax configurations in the system. This endpoint provides access to tax rates, names, descriptions, and applicability rules used throughout the application for financial calculations and compliance.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/taxes`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
- **per_page** (integer, optional): Number of tax records to return per page (default: 25, max: 100)
- **page** (integer, optional): Page number for pagination (default: 1)
- **is_active** (boolean, optional): Filter by active status (true/false)
- **applies_to** (string, optional): Filter by application scope (sales, purchases, both)
- **search** (string, optional): Search tax names or descriptions

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
None

## Response Format
Returns a paginated JSON array of tax objects with metadata:
```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "name": "Sales Tax",
      "rate": 5.00,
      "description": "Standard sales tax",
      "is_active": true,
      "is_compound": false,
      "applies_to": "sales",
      "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
      "updated_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"
    }
  ],
  "meta": {
    "current_page": 1,
    "per_page": 25,
    "total": 50,
    "last_page": 2
  }
}
```

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Tax list retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view taxes
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Invalid query parameters
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Display all available tax configurations in admin panel
- Populate tax selection dropdowns in transaction forms
- Audit tax rates for compliance reporting
- Export tax configurations for accounting systems
- Filter active taxes for current financial calculations
- Review tax applicability rules across sales and purchases

## Notes
- Results are paginated to optimize performance with large tax datasets
- Inactive taxes are included by default unless filtered
- Tax rates are returned as decimal percentages (5.00 = 5%)
- Compound taxes apply on top of other taxes in calculation order
- Use filtering to retrieve only relevant taxes for specific workflows

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Creates a new tax configuration in the system. This endpoint allows administrators to define new tax rates, names, descriptions, and applicability rules for use in financial transactions and compliance calculations.

## HTTP Method & URL
**POST** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/taxes`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
JSON object containing the new tax configuration details:
```json
{
  "name": "Sales Tax",
  "rate": 5.00,
  "description": "Standard sales tax for retail transactions",
  "is_active": true,
  "is_compound": false,
  "applies_to": "sales"
}
```

**Required Fields:**
- **name** (string): Unique tax name (max 255 characters)
- **rate** (decimal): Tax rate as percentage (0.00 to 100.00)

**Optional Fields:**
- **description** (string): Detailed tax description
- **is_active** (boolean): Active status (default: true)
- **is_compound** (boolean): Whether tax compounds on other taxes (default: false)
- **applies_to** (string): Application scope - "sales", "purchases", or "both" (default: "sales")

## Response Format
Returns the newly created tax object with generated ID and timestamps:
```json
{
  "id": 1,
  "name": "Sales Tax",
  "rate": 5.00,
  "description": "Standard sales tax for retail transactions",
  "is_active": true,
  "is_compound": false,
  "applies_to": "sales",
  "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"
}
```

## Status Codes
- **201 Created** - Tax created successfully
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request data format
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to create taxes
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (duplicate name, invalid rate, missing required fields)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Add new tax rates for different jurisdictions
- Configure sales tax for e-commerce transactions
- Set up VAT for international sales
- Create compound taxes for multi-tier tax systems
- Define purchase taxes for procurement workflows
- Establish tax rules for compliance with local regulations

## Notes
- Tax names must be unique across the system
- Rate must be a positive decimal value (percentage)
- Compound taxes are calculated after base taxes
- Inactive taxes are not applied to new transactions but remain in historical records
- Tax applicability determines which transaction types use this tax
- Created taxes are immediately available for use in transactions

- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Add new tax rates for different jurisdictions
- Configure sales tax for e-commerce transactions
- Set up VAT for international sales
- Create compound taxes for multi-tier tax systems
- Define purchase taxes for procurement workflows
- Establish tax rules for compliance with local regulations

## Notes
- Tax names must be unique across the system
- Rate must be a positive decimal value (percentage)
- Compound taxes are calculated after base taxes
- Inactive taxes are not applied to new transactions but remain in historical records
- Tax applicability determines which transaction types use this tax
- Created taxes are immediately available for use in transactions

## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves detailed information about a specific tax configuration by its unique identifier. This endpoint provides complete tax details including rates, names, descriptions, active status, compound settings, and applicability rules.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/taxes/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the tax to retrieve

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
None

## Response Format
Returns a single tax object with complete configuration details:
```json
{
  "id": 1,
  "name": "Sales Tax",
  "rate": 5.00,
  "description": "Standard sales tax for retail transactions",
  "is_active": true,
  "is_compound": false,
  "applies_to": "sales",
  "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"
}
```

**Response Fields:**
- **id** (integer): Unique tax identifier
- **name** (string): Tax name
- **rate** (decimal): Tax rate as percentage
- **description** (string): Detailed tax description
- **is_active** (boolean): Whether tax is currently active
- **is_compound** (boolean): Whether tax compounds on other taxes
- **applies_to** (string): Application scope (sales, purchases, both)
- **created_at** (timestamp): Tax creation date and time
- **updated_at** (timestamp): Last modification date and time

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Tax retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view tax details
- **404 Not Found** - Tax with specified ID does not exist
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Display tax details in admin configuration panels
- Retrieve tax information for transaction calculations
- Verify tax rates before applying to invoices or orders
- Audit specific tax configurations for compliance
- Populate tax edit forms with current values
- Validate tax applicability for specific transaction types
- Review tax settings before making updates
- Export individual tax configurations for reporting

## Notes
- Tax ID must be a valid integer corresponding to an existing tax record
- Inactive taxes can still be retrieved for historical reference
- Tax rate is returned as decimal percentage (5.00 = 5%)
- Compound taxes are applied after base taxes in calculation workflows
- Use this endpoint to verify tax details before updates or deletions
- Response includes audit timestamps for tracking configuration changes

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Updates an existing tax configuration in the system. This endpoint allows modification of tax details including rates, names, descriptions, and applicability rules to reflect legislative changes or correct configuration errors.

## HTTP Method & URL
**PUT** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/taxes/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the tax to update

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
JSON object containing fields to update (only include fields you want to change):
```json
{
  "name": "VAT",
  "rate": 10.00,
  "description": "Value Added Tax for goods and services",
  "is_active": true,
  "is_compound": false,
  "applies_to": "both"
}
```

**Updatable Fields:**
- **name** (string): Tax name (max 255 characters, must be unique)
- **rate** (decimal): Tax rate percentage (0.00 to 100.00)
- **description** (string): Tax description
- **is_active** (boolean): Active status
- **is_compound** (boolean): Whether tax compounds on other taxes
- **applies_to** (string): Application scope - "sales", "purchases", or "both"

## Response Format
Returns the updated tax object with modified fields and updated timestamp:
```json
{
  "id": 1,
  "name": "VAT",
  "rate": 10.00,
  "description": "Value Added Tax for goods and services",
  "is_active": true,
  "is_compound": false,
  "applies_to": "both",
  "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-01-20T14:45:00Z"
}
```

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Tax updated successfully
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request data format
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to update taxes
- **404 Not Found** - Tax with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (invalid rate, duplicate name, missing required fields)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Update tax rates due to legislation changes
- Modify tax names or descriptions for clarity
- Activate or deactivate tax rules based on jurisdiction requirements
- Adjust compound tax settings for multi-tier calculations
- Change tax applicability scope between sales and purchases
- Correct tax configuration errors or inconsistencies
- Align tax rates with regulatory compliance updates

## Notes
- Only include fields you want to update in the request body
- Rate changes apply to new transactions only; historical transactions remain unchanged
- Deactivating a tax prevents it from being applied to new transactions
- Tax name must remain unique if changed
- Compound tax changes affect calculation order in multi-tax scenarios
- Updates are logged for audit and compliance tracking
- Consider the impact on existing transactions and financial reports before making changes

The ID of the tax.

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Deletes a tax configuration from the system. This endpoint permanently removes a tax record, preventing its use in future transactions. Use with caution as this action may impact historical data references and financial reporting.

## HTTP Method & URL
**DELETE** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/taxes/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the tax to delete

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
None

## Response Format
Returns a success confirmation message:
```json
{
  "message": "Tax deleted successfully",
  "id": 1
}
```

Alternatively, may return an empty response with 204 status code.

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Tax deleted successfully with confirmation message
- **204 No Content** - Tax deleted successfully without response body
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to delete taxes
- **404 Not Found** - Tax with specified ID does not exist
- **409 Conflict** - Tax cannot be deleted due to existing references in transactions
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Tax is in use and cannot be deleted
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Remove obsolete tax configurations no longer required
- Clean up duplicate or test tax entries
- Delete incorrectly created tax records
- Remove taxes for jurisdictions no longer serviced
- Maintain clean tax configuration database
- Eliminate unused taxes to simplify tax selection interfaces

## Notes
- Deletion is permanent and cannot be undone
- Taxes referenced in existing transactions typically cannot be deleted
- Consider deactivating taxes instead of deleting to preserve historical data integrity
- Some systems may implement soft deletion, marking taxes as deleted rather than removing them
- Deletion may be restricted if the tax has been used in any financial calculations
- Always verify the tax is not in use before attempting deletion
- Backup tax configurations before performing deletions
- Deletion may require additional confirmation or elevated permissions
- Historical reports referencing deleted taxes may show incomplete data

item.description:
## Overview
The Taxes resource manages tax rate configuration and calculation rules in the Invent-MAG system. This enables accurate tax computation for sales and purchase transactions, ensuring compliance with tax regulations and proper financial reporting.

## Purpose
Taxes define the various tax rates, rules, and jurisdictions applicable to business transactions. This resource supports complex tax scenarios including multiple tax types, compound taxes, tax exemptions, and jurisdiction-specific rates, ensuring accurate tax calculation and reporting.

## Key Functionality
- Configure multiple tax rates and types
- Support various tax types (VAT, GST, sales tax, etc.)
- Define tax jurisdictions and regions
- Handle compound and cascading taxes
- Support tax exemptions and special rates
- Enable product-specific tax rules
- Configure customer tax categories
- Track tax collection and remittance
- Generate tax reports and returns

## Common Operations
- **GET /taxes** - List all tax configurations with rates and rules
- **GET /taxes/{id}** - Retrieve specific tax configuration details
- **POST /taxes** - Create new tax rates or rules
- **PUT/PATCH /taxes/{id}** - Update tax rates, rules, or jurisdictions
- **DELETE /taxes/{id}** - Remove tax configurations (requires no active transactions)

## Relationships
- **Products**: Products may have specific tax rates or exemptions
- **Customers**: Customer tax categories affect applicable rates
- **Suppliers**: Supplier locations determine purchase tax treatment
- **Sales Orders**: Tax calculations on customer invoices
- **Purchase Orders**: Tax calculations on supplier invoices
- **Sales Items**: Line-item tax calculations
- **Purchase Order Items**: Line-item tax calculations
- **POS**: Point-of-sale tax calculations
- **Accounts**: Tax collected/paid affects specific accounts
- **Journal Entries**: Tax transactions create accounting entries
- **Transactions**: Tax amounts in financial records

## Important Fields
- Tax name and description
- Tax type (sales tax, VAT, GST, excise, etc.)
- Tax rate (percentage)
- Tax jurisdiction or region
- Effective date range
- Active/inactive status
- Compound tax flag
- Tax on tax rules
- Exemption criteria
- Product applicability
- Customer category applicability
- Tax authority information
- Reporting codes
- Rounding rules

## Business Context
Use these endpoints when:
- Setting up initial tax configuration
- Updating tax rates for regulatory changes
- Configuring multi-jurisdiction tax rules
- Processing sales with correct tax calculations
- Managing tax exemptions
- Generating tax reports and filings
- Reconciling tax collected vs. remitted
- Supporting international transactions
- Handling special tax scenarios
- Auditing tax calculations
- Integrating with accounting systems
- Ensuring tax compliance
- Managing tax authority requirements

item.name: Transactions

query.description: The number of transactions to return per page. Defaults to 15.

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves a paginated list of all financial transactions in the system. This endpoint returns transaction records including journal entries, account transactions, debit/credit entries, and other financial activities recorded in the double-entry bookkeeping system.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/transactions?per_page=25`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
- **per_page** (integer, optional): Number of transactions to return per page. Default is 25. Use for pagination control.
- **page** (integer, optional): Page number for pagination. Default is 1.

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for GET requests.

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing:
- Array of transaction objects with fields:
  - `id`: Unique transaction identifier
  - `journal_entry_id`: Associated journal entry reference
  - `account_id`: Account affected by this transaction
  - `type`: Transaction type (debit or credit)
  - `amount`: Transaction amount (decimal format)
  - `date`: Transaction date
  - `reference`: Reference number or code
  - `description`: Transaction description
  - `status`: Transaction status (posted, pending, voided)
  - `created_by`: User who created the transaction
  - `created_at`: Timestamp of creation
  - `updated_at`: Timestamp of last update
- Pagination metadata (total count, current page, per_page, last_page)
- Links for navigation (first, last, prev, next)

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Transactions retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view transactions
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Invalid query parameters
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Display transaction history and financial activity logs
- Generate financial reports and statements
- Audit financial activities and compliance tracking
- Track cash flow and account movements
- Reconcile accounts and verify balances
- Export transaction data for external analysis
- Monitor business financial activity in real-time
- Review journal entry details and double-entry records
- Analyze debit/credit patterns across accounts

## Notes
- Results are paginated for performance optimization with large datasets
- Transactions follow double-entry bookkeeping principles (every debit has a corresponding credit)
- Each transaction is linked to a journal entry for complete audit trail
- Transaction types include: debit (increases assets/expenses, decreases liabilities/equity/revenue) and credit (increases liabilities/equity/revenue, decreases assets/expenses)
- Use filters to narrow results by date range, account, type, or status
- Posted transactions affect account balances; pending transactions do not
- Essential for financial reporting, analysis, and maintaining accurate accounting records
- Supports comprehensive financial auditing and regulatory compliance

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Creates a new financial transaction record in the accounting system. This endpoint allows you to record individual debit or credit transactions as part of journal entries, maintaining double-entry bookkeeping principles. Each transaction affects a specific account and must be balanced with corresponding entries.

## HTTP Method & URL
**POST** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/transactions`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Required JSON object with the following fields:
- **journal_entry_id** (integer, required): The ID of the journal entry this transaction belongs to. Links transaction to parent journal entry for double-entry tracking.
- **account_id** (integer, required): The ID of the account affected by this transaction. Must be a valid account in the chart of accounts.
- **type** (string, required): Transaction type - either "debit" or "credit". Debit increases assets/expenses, decreases liabilities/equity/revenue. Credit does the opposite.
- **amount** (decimal, required): Transaction amount in decimal format (e.g., "50.00"). Must be positive value.
- **description** (string, optional): Detailed description of the transaction purpose
- **reference** (string, optional): Reference number or code linking to source document
- **date** (date, optional): Transaction date. Defaults to current date if not provided.

**Example Request Body:**
```json
{
  "journal_entry_id": 1,
  "account_id": 1,
  "type": "credit",
  "amount": "50.00",
  "description": "Payment received from customer",
  "reference": "INV-2024-001"
}
```

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing the newly created transaction:
- **id**: Unique identifier for the created transaction
- **journal_entry_id**: Associated journal entry reference
- **account_id**: Account affected by this transaction
- **account**: Complete account details
- **type**: Transaction type (debit or credit)
- **amount**: Transaction amount
- **description**: Transaction description
- **reference**: Reference number
- **date**: Transaction date
- **status**: Initial status (typically "pending" or "posted")
- **created_by**: User who created the transaction
- **created_at**: Timestamp of creation
- **updated_at**: Timestamp of last update

## Status Codes
- **201 Created** - Transaction created successfully
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request data or missing required fields
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to create transactions
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (invalid account, amount, or type)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Record sales revenue transactions (credit to revenue account)
- Record expense transactions (debit to expense account)
- Record payment receipts (debit to cash, credit to accounts receivable)
- Record payment disbursements (credit to cash, debit to accounts payable)
- Create asset purchase transactions (debit to asset account)
- Record liability transactions (credit to liability account)
- Post journal entry transactions for period-end adjustments
- Record inventory transactions (debit/credit to inventory accounts)
- Create equity transactions (capital contributions, withdrawals)

## Notes
- Transactions must be part of a valid journal entry for double-entry bookkeeping
- Every debit transaction should have a corresponding credit transaction (and vice versa) within the same journal entry
- Transaction type must be either "debit" or "credit" - case sensitive
- Amount must be positive; the type determines the account impact direction
- Account must exist and be active in the chart of accounts
- Journal entry must be in editable status to add transactions
- Once posted, transactions affect account balances immediately
- Maintains complete audit trail with timestamps and user tracking
- Essential for accurate financial record-keeping and compliance
- Supports comprehensive accounting workflows and financial reporting

Required JSON object with the following fields:
- **journal_entry_id** (integer, required): The ID of the journal entry this transaction belongs to. Links transaction to parent journal entry for double-entry tracking.
- **account_id** (integer, required): The ID of the account affected by this transaction. Must be a valid account in the chart of accounts.
- **type** (string, required): Transaction type - either "debit" or "credit". Debit increases assets/expenses, decreases liabilities/equity/revenue. Credit does the opposite.
- **amount** (decimal, required): Transaction amount in decimal format (e.g., "50.00"). Must be positive value.
- **description** (string, optional): Detailed description of the transaction purpose
- **reference** (string, optional): Reference number or code linking to source document
- **date** (date, optional): Transaction date. Defaults to current date if not provided.

**Example Request Body:**
```json
{
  "journal_entry_id": 1,
  "account_id": 1,
  "type": "credit",
  "amount": "50.00",
  "description": "Payment received from customer",
  "reference": "INV-2024-001"
}
```

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing the newly created transaction:
- **id**: Unique identifier for the created transaction
- **journal_entry_id**: Associated journal entry reference
- **account_id**: Account affected by this transaction
- **account**: Complete account details
- **type**: Transaction type (debit or credit)
- **amount**: Transaction amount
- **description**: Transaction description
- **reference**: Reference number
- **date**: Transaction date
- **status**: Initial status (typically "pending" or "posted")
- **created_by**: User who created the transaction
- **created_at**: Timestamp of creation
- **updated_at**: Timestamp of last update

## Status Codes
- **201 Created** - Transaction created successfully
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request data or missing required fields
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to create transactions
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (invalid account, amount, or type)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Record sales revenue transactions (credit to revenue account)
- Record expense transactions (debit to expense account)
- Record payment receipts (debit to cash, credit to accounts receivable)
- Record payment disbursements (credit to cash, debit to accounts payable)
- Create asset purchase transactions (debit to asset account)
- Record liability transactions (credit to liability account)
- Post journal entry transactions for period-end adjustments
- Record inventory transactions (debit/credit to inventory accounts)
- Create equity transactions (capital contributions, withdrawals)

## Notes
- Transactions must be part of a valid journal entry for double-entry bookkeeping
- Every debit transaction should have a corresponding credit transaction (and vice versa) within the same journal entry
- Transaction type must be either "debit" or "credit" - case sensitive
- Amount must be positive; the type determines the account impact direction
- Account must exist and be active in the chart of accounts
- Journal entry must be in editable status to add transactions
- Once posted, transactions affect account balances immediately
- Maintains complete audit trail with timestamps and user tracking
- Essential for accurate financial record-keeping and compliance
- Supports comprehensive accounting workflows and financial reporting

## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves detailed information about a specific financial transaction by its unique identifier. This endpoint returns comprehensive transaction data including amounts, account details, journal entry associations, transaction type (debit/credit), and related accounting records for double-entry bookkeeping verification.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/transactions/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the transaction to retrieve

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for GET requests.

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing complete transaction details:
- **id**: Unique transaction identifier
- **journal_entry_id**: Associated journal entry reference for double-entry tracking
- **account_id**: Account affected by this transaction
- **account**: Complete account information (code, name, type, balance)
- **type**: Transaction type (debit or credit)
- **amount**: Transaction amount in decimal format
- **date**: Transaction date
- **reference**: Reference number linking to source document
- **description**: Detailed transaction description
- **status**: Transaction status (posted, pending, voided)
- **related_entity**: Source document (sales order, purchase order, payment, receipt, adjustment)
- **approval_info**: Approval status and approver details
- **created_by**: User information who created the transaction
- **created_at**: Timestamp of creation
- **updated_at**: Timestamp of last update
- **balance_impact**: How this transaction affected the account balance

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Transaction retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view transaction details
- **404 Not Found** - Transaction with specified ID does not exist
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Display detailed transaction information for review
- Audit specific transactions for compliance verification
- Retrieve transaction for account reconciliation
- View complete transaction breakdown including journal entry
- Track transaction source and related documents
- Generate detailed transaction reports
- Verify double-entry bookkeeping accuracy
- Review debit/credit impact on account balances
- Investigate transaction discrepancies or errors

## Notes
- Returns complete transaction information including all relationships and metadata
- Use this endpoint for detailed transaction review and auditing
- Transaction type indicates whether it's a debit (increases assets/expenses) or credit (increases liabilities/equity/revenue)
- Reference numbers link back to source documents for complete audit trail
- Status shows if transaction is posted (affects balances) or pending (does not affect balances yet)
- Each transaction is part of a journal entry maintaining double-entry bookkeeping integrity
- Essential for financial auditing, reconciliation, and maintaining accurate accounting records
- Provides full visibility into transaction lifecycle and approval workflow

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Updates an existing financial transaction record in the accounting system. This endpoint allows you to modify transaction details such as amount, account, type (debit/credit), or associated journal entry. Use this to correct errors or adjust transactions before they are posted and affect account balances.

## HTTP Method & URL
**PUT** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/transactions/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the transaction to update

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
JSON object with fields to update (all fields are optional, only include fields you want to change):
- **journal_entry_id** (integer, optional): Update the journal entry this transaction belongs to
- **account_id** (integer, optional): Change the account affected by this transaction. Must be a valid account in the chart of accounts.
- **type** (string, optional): Update transaction type - either "debit" or "credit"
- **amount** (decimal, optional): Update transaction amount in decimal format (e.g., "100.00"). Must be positive value.
- **description** (string, optional): Update transaction description
- **reference** (string, optional): Update reference number or code
- **date** (date, optional): Update transaction date

**Example Request Body:**
```json
{
  "journal_entry_id": 1,
  "account_id": 1,
  "type": "debit",
  "amount": "100.00",
  "description": "Corrected payment amount",
  "reference": "INV-2024-001-REV"
}
```

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing the updated transaction:
- **id**: Transaction identifier
- **journal_entry_id**: Associated journal entry reference
- **account_id**: Account affected by this transaction
- **account**: Complete account details
- **type**: Transaction type (debit or credit)
- **amount**: Updated transaction amount
- **description**: Updated transaction description
- **reference**: Updated reference number
- **date**: Transaction date
- **status**: Transaction status
- **created_by**: Original creator
- **updated_by**: User who made the update
- **created_at**: Original creation timestamp
- **updated_at**: Timestamp of this update

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Transaction updated successfully
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request data
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to update transactions
- **404 Not Found** - Transaction with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (invalid account, amount, type, or posted transaction)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Correct transaction amounts before posting
- Update account assignments for proper categorization
- Change transaction type (debit to credit or vice versa)
- Update descriptions for clarity and audit purposes
- Modify reference numbers to match source documents
- Adjust transaction dates for accurate period reporting
- Reassign transactions to different journal entries
- Fix data entry errors before financial close
- Update pending transactions before they affect balances

## Notes
- Only pending/draft transactions can typically be updated; posted transactions may require reversal entries
- Updating transaction type or amount may affect journal entry balance - ensure double-entry integrity is maintained
- Changes to posted transactions may require special permissions or approval workflow
- Account must exist and be active in the chart of accounts
- Transaction type must be either "debit" or "credit" - case sensitive
- Amount must be positive; the type determines the account impact direction
- Maintains complete audit trail showing who updated and when
- Journal entry must remain balanced after transaction updates
- Consider creating reversing entries instead of updating posted transactions for better audit trail
- Essential for maintaining accurate financial records and correcting errors
- Updates are logged for compliance and auditing purposes

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Deletes a specific financial transaction record from the accounting system. This endpoint permanently removes a transaction from the database. Use with caution as this action may affect journal entry balances and double-entry bookkeeping integrity. Typically only allowed for pending/draft transactions that haven't been posted.

## HTTP Method & URL
**DELETE** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/transactions/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the transaction to delete

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for DELETE requests.

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object confirming the deletion:
- **message**: Success message confirming deletion
- **deleted_transaction_id**: ID of the deleted transaction
- **status**: Deletion status

**Example Response:**
```json
{
  "message": "Transaction deleted successfully",
  "deleted_transaction_id": 1,
  "status": "success"
}
```

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Transaction deleted successfully
- **204 No Content** - Transaction deleted successfully (no response body)
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to delete transactions or transaction is posted
- **404 Not Found** - Transaction with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Cannot delete posted transaction or transaction is part of closed period
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Remove duplicate transaction entries
- Delete incorrect transactions before posting
- Clean up draft transactions that are no longer needed
- Remove test transactions from development/staging
- Delete pending transactions that were created in error
- Remove transactions from cancelled journal entries
- Clean up incomplete or abandoned transaction records

## Notes
- **CAUTION**: This action is typically irreversible and permanently removes the transaction
- Only pending/draft transactions should be deletable; posted transactions usually require reversal entries instead
- Deleting a transaction may unbalance the associated journal entry - ensure double-entry integrity is maintained
- Posted transactions that affect account balances should NOT be deleted; use reversing entries instead
- Transactions in closed accounting periods typically cannot be deleted
- Requires appropriate permissions - usually restricted to accounting managers or administrators
- Deletion is logged in audit trail for compliance and tracking
- Consider the impact on related journal entries before deleting
- Best practice: Use void/reversal entries for posted transactions rather than deletion
- Some systems may implement soft deletes (marking as deleted) rather than hard deletes for audit purposes
- Ensure journal entry remains balanced after transaction deletion
- Essential to maintain data integrity and comply with accounting standards and regulations

item.description:
## Overview
The Transactions resource provides a comprehensive view of all financial movements in the Invent-MAG system. This serves as the central ledger for tracking every monetary transaction, providing complete financial visibility and audit trails.

## Purpose
Transactions record every financial event affecting the business, including sales revenue, purchase costs, payments, receipts, adjustments, and transfers. This resource provides the foundation for financial reporting, reconciliation, and analysis, ensuring complete accountability for all monetary activities.

## Key Functionality
- Record all financial transactions automatically
- Track transaction sources (sales, purchases, payments, etc.)
- Maintain complete audit trails
- Support multi-currency transactions
- Enable transaction categorization
- Provide real-time financial visibility
- Support transaction reconciliation
- Generate transaction reports and summaries
- Enable financial analysis and trending

## Common Operations
- **GET /transactions** - List all transactions with filtering by date, type, account, amount
- **GET /transactions/{id}** - Retrieve detailed transaction record
- **POST /transactions** - Create manual transactions (typically system-generated)
- **PUT/PATCH /transactions/{id}** - Update transaction details or categorization
- **DELETE /transactions/{id}** - Remove transactions (typically restricted)

## Relationships
- **Accounts**: Transactions affect specific accounts
- **Journal Entries**: Transactions may generate journal entries
- **Sales Orders**: Sales create revenue transactions
- **Purchase Orders**: Purchases create expense transactions
- **Payments**: Payment processing creates transactions
- **Customers**: Customer-related transactions
- **Suppliers**: Supplier-related transactions
- **Products**: Product sales or purchases
- **Warehouses**: Location-specific transactions
- **Users**: Transaction created or approved by users
- **Currency Settings**: Multi-currency transaction support

## Important Fields
- Transaction date and time
- Transaction type (sale, purchase, payment, receipt, adjustment, transfer)
- Transaction amount and currency
- Debit and credit accounts
- Reference number
- Description and notes
- Source document (invoice, receipt, order)
- Transaction status (pending, posted, reconciled, voided)
- Exchange rate (for foreign currency)
- Related entity (customer, supplier, product)
- Created by user
- Approval information
- Reconciliation status

## Business Context
Use these endpoints when:
- Reviewing financial activity
- Reconciling bank statements
- Generating financial reports
- Auditing financial records
- Analyzing cash flow
- Tracking revenue and expenses
- Monitoring account balances
- Supporting financial close processes
- Investigating discrepancies
- Generating tax reports
- Integrating with accounting systems
- Providing financial transparency
- Supporting compliance and audits

item.name: Units

query.description: The number of units to return per page. Defaults to 15.

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves a paginated list of all units of measurement in the system. This endpoint returns comprehensive unit information including names, symbols, types, and conversion factors for inventory and product management.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/units`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
- **per_page** (integer, optional): Number of units to return per page (default: 25, max: 100)
- **page** (integer, optional): Page number for pagination (default: 1)
- **search** (string, optional): Search term to filter units by name or symbol
- **type** (string, optional): Filter by unit type (weight, volume, length, quantity, area, time)
- **system** (string, optional): Filter by unit system (metric, imperial, custom)
- **sort_by** (string, optional): Field to sort by (name, symbol, type, created_at)
- **sort_order** (string, optional): Sort direction (asc, desc)

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for GET requests.

## Response Format
Returns a paginated JSON object containing an array of unit objects with metadata:
```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "name": "Kilogram",
      "symbol": "kg",
      "type": "weight",
      "system": "metric",
      "base_unit_id": null,
      "conversion_factor": 1.0,
      "description": "Standard unit of mass",
      "is_active": true,
      "created_at": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z",
      "updated_at": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z"
    }
  ],
  "meta": {
    "current_page": 1,
    "per_page": 25,
    "total": 50,
    "last_page": 2
  }
}
```

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Units retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view units
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Invalid query parameters
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- List all available units for product configuration
- Search for specific units by name or symbol
- Filter units by type for category-specific operations
- Retrieve metric or imperial units for regional settings
- Display unit options in dropdown menus
- Audit unit inventory for system standardization
- Export unit data for reporting

## Notes
- Results are paginated to optimize performance
- Default sorting is by unit name in ascending order
- Inactive units may be excluded from results by default
- Standard units (kg, g, L, mL, pc, m, cm) are system-defined
- Custom units can be created for specific business needs
- Unit symbols should be unique across the system
- Conversion factors are relative to base units within each type
- Use appropriate units for product measurements to ensure accurate inventory tracking
- Consider regional preferences when selecting unit systems

- List all available units for product configuration
- Search for specific units by name or symbol
- Filter units by type for category-specific operations
- Retrieve metric or imperial units for regional settings
- Display unit options in dropdown menus
- Audit unit inventory for system standardization
- Export unit data for reporting

## Notes
- Results are paginated to optimize performance
- Default sorting is by unit name in ascending order
- Inactive units may be excluded from results by default
- Standard units (kg, g, L, mL, pc, m, cm) are system-defined
- Custom units can be created for specific business needs
- Unit symbols should be unique across the system
- Conversion factors are relative to base units within each type
- Use appropriate units for product measurements to ensure accurate inventory tracking
- Consider regional preferences when selecting unit systems

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Creates a new unit of measurement in the system. This endpoint allows adding custom units for specialized inventory tracking, product measurements, and business-specific requirements.

## HTTP Method & URL
**POST** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/units`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
JSON object containing the unit details:
```json
{
  "name": "Piece",
  "symbol": "pc",
  "type": "quantity",
  "system": "custom",
  "description": "Individual countable item",
  "base_unit_id": null,
  "conversion_factor": 1.0,
  "is_active": true
}
```

**Required Fields:**
- **name** (string): Full name of the unit (e.g., "Kilogram", "Liter", "Piece")
- **symbol** (string): Short abbreviation for the unit (e.g., "kg", "L", "pc")

**Optional Fields:**
- **type** (string): Unit category - weight, volume, length, quantity, area, time (default: "quantity")
- **system** (string): Unit system - metric, imperial, custom (default: "custom")
- **description** (string): Detailed description of the unit and its usage
- **base_unit_id** (integer): Reference to base unit for conversion calculations (null for base units)
- **conversion_factor** (decimal): Multiplier to convert to base unit (default: 1.0)
- **is_active** (boolean): Whether the unit is active and available for use (default: true)

## Response Format
Returns the created unit object with generated ID and timestamps:
```json
{
  "id": 15,
  "name": "Piece",
  "symbol": "pc",
  "type": "quantity",
  "system": "custom",
  "base_unit_id": null,
  "conversion_factor": 1.0,
  "description": "Individual countable item",
  "is_active": true,
  "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"
}
```

## Status Codes
- **201 Created** - Unit created successfully
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request data format
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to create units
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (duplicate name/symbol, invalid type, invalid conversion factor)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Add custom units for specialized products (dozen, bundle, case)
- Create industry-specific measurement units
- Define packaging units (box, carton, pallet)
- Add regional or traditional units
- Set up units for raw materials
- Configure units for recipe measurements
- Establish units for service-based products

## Notes
- Unit names and symbols must be unique across the system
- Symbols should be short (2-5 characters) and recognizable
- Use standard abbreviations when possible (kg, g, L, mL, m, cm)
- Set appropriate conversion factors for accurate calculations
- Base units should have conversion_factor of 1.0
- Related units should reference the same base unit
- Consider creating both singular and plural forms if needed
- Inactive units are hidden from product configuration but preserved in historical data
- Custom units can be modified or deactivated but not deleted if used in products
- Ensure unit types match the products they will measure
- Document custom units clearly for team understanding

## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves detailed information about a specific unit of measurement by its unique identifier. This endpoint returns comprehensive unit data including name, symbol, type, conversion factors, and usage information.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/units/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the unit to retrieve

## Query Parameters
- **include** (string, optional): Comma-separated list of related data to include (products, conversions, base_unit)

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for GET requests.

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing the unit details:
```json
{
  "id": 1,
  "name": "Kilogram",
  "symbol": "kg",
  "type": "weight",
  "system": "metric",
  "base_unit_id": null,
  "conversion_factor": 1.0,
  "description": "Standard unit of mass in the metric system",
  "is_active": true,
  "products_count": 150,
  "created_at": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "related_units": [
    {
      "id": 2,
      "name": "Gram",
      "symbol": "g",
      "conversion_factor": 0.001
    }
  ]
}
```

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Unit retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view unit details
- **404 Not Found** - Unit with specified ID does not exist
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- View complete details of a specific unit
- Retrieve unit information for product configuration
- Check unit properties before updating
- Verify unit conversion factors and relationships
- Display unit details in admin interfaces
- Audit unit configuration and usage
- Validate unit data for inventory calculations
- Review unit metadata for reporting
- Inspect base unit relationships
- Confirm unit system and type classifications

## Notes
- Returns full unit details including metadata and timestamps
- Use the `include` parameter to fetch related data in a single request
- The `products_count` field shows how many products use this unit
- Base units have `base_unit_id` set to null and `conversion_factor` of 1.0
- Related units share the same base unit for conversion purposes
- Inactive units (is_active: false) are still retrievable but hidden from product configuration
- Standard system units cannot be deleted but can be viewed
- Conversion factors are relative to the base unit within the same type
- Use this endpoint to verify unit data before performing updates
- Check unit usage before attempting deletion
- Unit symbols and names are unique identifiers within the system
- Historical data references are preserved even for inactive units

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Updates an existing unit of measurement in the system. This endpoint allows modification of unit details including name, symbol, type, description, and conversion factors for maintaining accurate inventory and product measurements.

## HTTP Method & URL
**PUT** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/units/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the unit to update

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
JSON object containing fields to update (only include fields you want to change):
```json
{
  "name": "Kilogram",
  "symbol": "kg",
  "type": "weight",
  "system": "metric",
  "description": "Standard unit of mass in the metric system",
  "base_unit_id": null,
  "conversion_factor": 1.0,
  "is_active": true
}
```

**Updatable Fields:**
- **name** (string): Full name of the unit
- **symbol** (string): Short abbreviation for the unit
- **type** (string): Unit category - weight, volume, length, quantity, area, time
- **system** (string): Unit system - metric, imperial, custom
- **description** (string): Detailed description of the unit
- **base_unit_id** (integer): Reference to base unit for conversions (null for base units)
- **conversion_factor** (decimal): Multiplier for base unit conversion
- **is_active** (boolean): Whether the unit is active and available for use

## Response Format
Returns the updated unit object with modified fields and updated timestamp:
```json
{
  "id": 1,
  "name": "Kilogram",
  "symbol": "kg",
  "type": "weight",
  "system": "metric",
  "base_unit_id": null,
  "conversion_factor": 1.0,
  "description": "Standard unit of mass in the metric system",
  "is_active": true,
  "created_at": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-01-15T14:20:00Z"
}
```

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Unit updated successfully
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request data format
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to update units
- **404 Not Found** - Unit with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (duplicate name/symbol, invalid conversion factor, invalid type)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Update unit names or symbols for clarity
- Modify unit descriptions for better documentation
- Adjust conversion factors for accuracy
- Correct unit information errors
- Standardize unit naming conventions
- Change unit types or systems for proper categorization
- Deactivate obsolete units while preserving historical data
- Update base unit references for conversion chains
- Refine custom units based on business needs

## Notes
- Only include fields you want to update in the request body
- Unit names and symbols must remain unique after update
- Changing conversion factors affects all related calculations
- Updates to units used in products may impact inventory calculations
- Standard system units (kg, g, L, mL, pc) should be modified with caution
- Consider the impact on existing products and transactions before updating
- Deactivating units (is_active: false) hides them from new product configurations
- Inactive units remain in historical records and reports
- Cannot change base_unit_id if it creates circular references
- Conversion factor changes should be validated against base unit
- Document significant changes for audit and team awareness
- Test conversion calculations after updating factors

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Permanently removes a unit of measurement from the system. This endpoint deletes the specified unit and handles cleanup of associated records. Use with caution as this operation cannot be undone.

## HTTP Method & URL
**DELETE** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/units/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the unit to delete

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for DELETE requests.

## Response Format
Returns a success message or empty response with appropriate status code:
```json
{
  "message": "Unit deleted successfully",
  "deleted_id": 15
}
```

Or empty response with 204 status code.

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Unit deleted successfully with confirmation message
- **204 No Content** - Unit deleted successfully (no response body)
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to delete units
- **404 Not Found** - Unit with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Cannot delete unit (has associated products, used in transactions, or is a base unit for other units)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Remove obsolete or duplicate units
- Clean up unused measurement units
- Delete test units from production environment
- Remove incorrectly created custom units
- Standardize unit systems by removing non-standard units
- Eliminate deprecated units after migration
- Clear out experimental units after testing

## Notes
- **IMPORTANT**: This operation is permanent and cannot be undone
- Units associated with products cannot be deleted
- Units used in active or historical transactions are protected from deletion
- Units serving as base units for other units cannot be deleted
- Reassign products to another unit before attempting deletion
- Consider deactivating units (is_active: false) instead of deleting to preserve historical data
- Deletion affects product records, inventory calculations, and reporting
- Standard system units (kg, g, L, mL, pc, m, cm) should never be deleted
- Ensure proper backup procedures are in place before deletion
- Verify no dependencies exist before deleting custom units
- Deletion may fail if unit is referenced in conversion chains
- Check for unit usage in recipes, BOMs, or formulations
- Document deletion reasons for audit purposes
- Alternative: Use soft delete by deactivating instead of permanent deletion

variable.description: The ID of the unit.
The ID of the unit to delete.

item.description:
## Overview
The Units resource manages measurement units used throughout the Invent-MAG inventory system. Units define how products are quantified, ordered, sold, and tracked, ensuring consistency and accuracy across all inventory operations.

## Purpose
Units provide standardized measurement definitions for products, supporting various unit types (weight, volume, length, count, etc.) and unit conversions. This enables accurate inventory tracking, ordering in different units, and proper quantity management across the system.

## Key Functionality
- Define standard and custom measurement units
- Support various unit types (pieces, kg, liters, meters, etc.)
- Enable unit conversions and relationships
- Configure base units and derived units
- Support fractional and decimal quantities
- Maintain unit abbreviations and symbols
- Enable multi-unit product management
- Support unit-specific pricing

## Common Operations
- **GET /units** - List all measurement units with details
- **GET /units/{id}** - Retrieve specific unit configuration
- **POST /units** - Create new measurement units
- **PUT/PATCH /units/{id}** - Update unit properties or conversions
- **DELETE /units/{id}** - Remove units (requires no products using them)

## Relationships
- **Products**: Products are measured in specific units
- **Sales Items**: Quantities sold in specific units
- **Purchase Order Items**: Quantities ordered in specific units
- **Stock Adjustments**: Inventory changes measured in units
- **Sales Opportunities**: Proposed quantities in units
- **POS**: Point-of-sale quantities in units

## Important Fields
- Unit name and description
- Unit abbreviation or symbol
- Unit type (weight, volume, length, count, area, etc.)
- Base unit flag
- Conversion factor (to base unit)
- Decimal precision
- Active/inactive status
- Display format
- Sorting order

## Business Context
Use these endpoints when:
- Setting up initial product catalog
- Configuring inventory management
- Adding new product types
- Supporting international standards
- Enabling unit conversions
- Managing bulk vs. retail units
- Configuring pricing by unit
- Supporting different packaging sizes
- Standardizing measurement across system
- Integrating with external systems
- Ensuring data consistency
- Supporting regulatory compliance

item.name: Users

query.description: The number of users to return per page. Defaults to 15.

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves a paginated list of all user accounts in the system. This endpoint provides access to user information including names, emails, roles, account status, and profile details for user management and administration purposes.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/users`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
- **per_page** (integer, optional): Number of users to return per page (default: 25, max: 100)
- **page** (integer, optional): Page number for pagination (default: 1)
- **search** (string, optional): Search term to filter users by name or email
- **role_id** (integer, optional): Filter users by specific role ID
- **is_active** (boolean, optional): Filter by account status (true for active, false for inactive)
- **sort_by** (string, optional): Field to sort by (name, email, created_at, updated_at)
- **sort_order** (string, optional): Sort direction (asc or desc)

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for GET requests.

## Response Format
Returns a paginated JSON object containing an array of user objects with metadata:
```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "name": "John Doe",
      "email": "john.doe@example.com",
      "role_id": 2,
      "role_name": "Manager",
      "is_active": true,
      "phone": "+1234567890",
      "department": "Sales",
      "avatar": "http://example.com/avatar.jpg",
      "timezone": "Asia/Jakarta",
      "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
      "updated_at": "2024-01-20T14:45:00Z"
    }
  ],
  "meta": {
    "current_page": 1,
    "per_page": 25,
    "total": 150,
    "last_page": 6
  }
}
```

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Users retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view users
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Invalid query parameters
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Display user directory for team management
- List all employees in the organization
- Search for specific users by name or email
- Filter users by role or department
- View active/inactive user accounts
- Export user lists for reporting
- Manage team member access and permissions

## Notes
- Passwords are never included in the response for security
- Results are paginated to optimize performance with large user bases
- Default pagination is 25 users per page
- Use search parameter for quick user lookup
- Inactive users are included by default unless filtered
- Requires appropriate permissions to view user list
- Response includes user role information for access control
- Timestamps are in UTC format
- Avatar URLs may be null if not set
- Consider caching results for frequently accessed user lists

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Creates a new user account in the system. This endpoint allows you to add users with specific roles, permissions, and access levels for system authentication and authorization.

## HTTP Method & URL
**POST** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/users`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
JSON object containing user information:
```json
{
  "name": "John Doe",
  "shopname": "John's Shop",
  "address": "123 Main St",
  "email": "john.doe@example.com",
  "password": "SecurePassword123!",
  "password_confirmation": "SecurePassword123!",
  "avatar": "http://example.com/avatar1.jpg",
  "timezone": "Asia/Jakarta",
  "role_id": 2,
  "is_active": true,
  "phone": "+1234567890",
  "department": "Sales",
  "system_settings": null,
  "accounting_settings": null
}
```

**Required Fields:**
- **name** (string): User's full name
- **email** (string): Unique email address for login and communication
- **password** (string): User password (minimum 8 characters, must include uppercase, lowercase, and numbers)
- **password_confirmation** (string): Password confirmation must match password

**Optional Fields:**
- **shopname** (string): Associated shop or store name
- **address** (string): Physical address
- **avatar** (string): URL to user profile image
- **timezone** (string): User's timezone (e.g., "Asia/Jakarta", "America/New_York")
- **role_id** (integer): Assigned role ID for permissions
- **is_active** (boolean): Account active status (default: true)
- **phone** (string): Contact phone number
- **department** (string): User's department or team
- **system_settings** (object): Custom system configuration
- **accounting_settings** (object): Accounting-specific settings

## Response Format
Returns the newly created user object with assigned ID, excluding password, and timestamps:
```json
{
  "id": 123,
  "name": "John Doe",
  "email": "john.doe@example.com",
  "shopname": "John's Shop",
  "address": "123 Main St",
  "avatar": "http://example.com/avatar1.jpg",
  "timezone": "Asia/Jakarta",
  "role_id": 2,
  "is_active": true,
  "phone": "+1234567890",
  "department": "Sales",
  "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"
}
```

## Status Codes
- **201 Created** - User created successfully
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request data format
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to create users
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (duplicate email, weak password, password mismatch, invalid role)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Onboard new team members to the system
- Create user accounts for new employees
- Set up user access for different departments
- Add staff members with specific roles and permissions
- Register users for shop or store management
- Configure user profiles with timezone and contact information
- Establish user authentication credentials

## Notes
- **Email must be unique** across the entire system
- Password must meet security requirements (minimum 8 characters)
- Password confirmation must exactly match the password field
- User email serves as the login username
- Passwords are encrypted before storage and never returned in responses
- Default timezone is applied if not specified
- Avatar URL should be publicly accessible
- Role ID determines user permissions and access levels
- New users are active by default unless specified otherwise
- System and accounting settings can be configured later
- Consider sending welcome email after user creation
- Validate email format before submission
- Phone numbers should include country code
- Shopname is useful for multi-tenant or marketplace systems

## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves detailed information about a specific user account by their unique identifier. This endpoint provides complete user profile data including personal information, role, account status, and settings.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/users/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the user to retrieve

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for GET requests.

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing the complete user profile:
```json
{
  "id": 1,
  "name": "John Doe",
  "email": "john.doe@example.com",
  "shopname": "John's Shop",
  "address": "123 Main St",
  "phone": "+1234567890",
  "avatar": "http://example.com/avatar1.jpg",
  "timezone": "Asia/Jakarta",
  "role_id": 2,
  "role_name": "Manager",
  "is_active": true,
  "department": "Sales",
  "system_settings": {
    "notifications_enabled": true,
    "theme": "light"
  },
  "accounting_settings": {
    "default_currency": "USD"
  },
  "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-01-20T14:45:00Z",
  "last_login_at": "2024-01-22T09:15:00Z"
}
```

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - User retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view this user
- **404 Not Found** - User with specified ID does not exist
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Display user profile page
- View detailed user information for administration
- Retrieve user data for editing forms
- Check user role and permissions
- Verify user account status
- Display user contact information
- Load user preferences and settings
- Audit user account details
- Validate user identity
- Retrieve user data for reports

## Notes
- Password is never included in the response for security reasons
- Requires authentication token to access user data
- Users may only view their own profile unless they have admin permissions
- Response includes role information for access control purposes
- Avatar URL may be null if no profile picture is set
- Timestamps are in UTC format
- System and accounting settings may be null if not configured
- Last login timestamp tracks user activity
- Inactive users (is_active: false) can still be retrieved but cannot log in
- Use this endpoint to verify user existence before performing operations
- Timezone affects how dates and times are displayed to the user
- Department and shopname fields are optional and may be null
- Consider caching user data for frequently accessed profiles
- Response structure may include additional custom fields based on system configuration

variable.description: The ID of the user.
The ID of the user.

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Updates an existing user account in the system. This endpoint allows modification of user details including name, email, role, account status, profile information, and credentials.

## HTTP Method & URL
**PUT** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/users/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the user to update

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
JSON object containing fields to update (only include fields you want to change):
```json
{
  "name": "Jane Doe",
  "shopname": "Jane's Shop",
  "address": "456 Oak Ave",
  "email": "jane.doe@example.com",
  "password": "NewPassword123!",
  "password_confirmation": "NewPassword123!",
  "avatar": "http://example.com/avatar2.jpg",
  "timezone": "America/New_York",
  "role_id": 3,
  "is_active": true,
  "phone": "+1234567890",
  "department": "Management",
  "system_settings": null,
  "accounting_settings": null
}
```

**Updatable Fields:**
- **name** (string): User's full name
- **email** (string): Email address (must be unique)
- **shopname** (string): Associated shop or store name
- **address** (string): Physical address
- **avatar** (string): URL to user profile image
- **timezone** (string): User's timezone
- **role_id** (integer): Assigned role for permissions
- **is_active** (boolean): Account active/inactive status
- **phone** (string): Contact phone number
- **department** (string): Department or team assignment
- **password** (string): New password (requires confirmation)
- **password_confirmation** (string): Password confirmation
- **system_settings** (object): Custom system configuration
- **accounting_settings** (object): Accounting-specific settings

## Response Format
Returns the updated user object with modified fields and updated timestamp, excluding password:
```json
{
  "id": 1,
  "name": "Jane Doe",
  "email": "jane.doe@example.com",
  "shopname": "Jane's Shop",
  "address": "456 Oak Ave",
  "avatar": "http://example.com/avatar2.jpg",
  "timezone": "America/New_York",
  "role_id": 3,
  "is_active": true,
  "phone": "+1234567890",
  "department": "Management",
  "created_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-01-20T14:45:00Z"
}
```

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - User updated successfully
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request data format
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to update users
- **404 Not Found** - User with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (duplicate email, weak password, password mismatch, invalid role)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Update user contact information (email, phone, address)
- Change user roles and permissions
- Activate or deactivate user accounts
- Reset user passwords
- Modify user profile details
- Update user department or team assignments
- Change user timezone settings
- Update shop or store associations
- Modify user avatar or profile picture
- Adjust user access levels

## Notes
- Only include fields you want to update in the request body
- Email must remain unique if changed
- Password update requires both password and password_confirmation fields
- Password must meet security requirements (minimum 8 characters)
- Cannot update another user's account without proper permissions
- Deactivating a user (is_active: false) prevents login but preserves data
- Role changes affect user permissions immediately
- Timezone changes affect date/time displays for the user
- Avatar URL should be publicly accessible
- System and accounting settings are optional and can be null
- Consider notifying users of significant account changes
- Audit logs may track user modifications
- Cannot change user ID or creation timestamp
- Email changes may require re-verification depending on system settings

variable.description: The ID of the user.
The ID of the user.
