## Endpoint Overview
Permanently removes a user account from the system. This endpoint deletes the specified user and handles cleanup of associated records.

## HTTP Method & URL
**DELETE** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/users/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the user to delete

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for DELETE requests.

## Response Format
Returns a success message or empty response with appropriate status code:
```json
{
  "message": "User deleted successfully"
}
```

Or empty response with 204 status code.

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - User deleted with confirmation message
- **204 No Content** - User deleted successfully (no response body)
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to delete users or attempting to delete own account
- **404 Not Found** - User with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Cannot delete user (has associated transactions, orders, or is the last admin)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Remove terminated employee accounts
- Delete duplicate user entries
- Clean up test users from production environment
- Remove inactive user accounts after retention period
- Delete user accounts upon request (GDPR compliance)
- Remove compromised or fraudulent accounts
- Clean up system after user offboarding

## Notes
- **IMPORTANT**: This operation is permanent and cannot be undone
- **Cannot delete your own user account** while logged in
- **Cannot delete the last administrator account** to prevent system lockout
- Users with transaction history, orders, or critical data may be protected from deletion
- **Consider deactivating users instead of deleting** to preserve audit trails and historical records
- Deletion may affect activity logs, reports, and historical records
- Reassign user's records, tasks, or ownership before deletion if needed
- Ensure proper backup procedures are in place before deletion
- Some systems may implement soft delete (marking as deleted) instead of hard delete
- Check for dependencies (assigned tasks, owned resources, etc.) before deletion
- Deletion may trigger cleanup of related data (sessions, tokens, preferences)
- **Alternative approach**: Set `is_active` to `false` rather than deleting to maintain data integrity
- Comply with data retention policies and legal requirements
- Document reason for deletion in audit logs
- Notify relevant stakeholders before deleting user accounts

item.description:
## Overview
The Users resource manages system user accounts and access in the Invent-MAG platform. This controls who can access the system, what they can do, and tracks user activity for security and accountability.

## Purpose
Users represent individuals who interact with the Invent-MAG system. This resource manages user authentication, profile information, role assignments, and activity tracking, ensuring secure access control and proper user management across the organization.

## Key Functionality
- Create and manage user accounts
- Configure user authentication credentials
- Assign roles and permissions
- Manage user profiles and preferences
- Track user activity and login history
- Support multi-factor authentication
- Enable/disable user accounts
- Manage API token generation
- Configure user notifications and alerts
- Support user groups and teams

## Common Operations
- **GET /users** - List all users with filtering by role, status, department
- **GET /users/{id}** - Retrieve detailed user profile and permissions
- **POST /users** - Create new user accounts
- **PUT/PATCH /users/{id}** - Update user information, roles, or status
- **DELETE /users/{id}** - Deactivate or remove user accounts

## Relationships
- **Roles**: Users are assigned one or more roles
- **Sales Orders**: Users create and process orders
- **Purchase Orders**: Users manage procurement
- **Customer Interactions**: Users log customer communications
- **Supplier Interactions**: Users manage supplier relationships
- **Sales Opportunities**: Users own and manage opportunities
- **Stock Adjustments**: Users record inventory changes
- **Payments**: Users process financial transactions
- **Journal Entries**: Users create accounting entries
- All Resources: Users create, modify, and access all system data

## Important Fields
- Username and email address
- Full name and display name
- Password (encrypted)
- Role assignments
- Department or team
- Active/inactive status
- Last login date and time
- Email verification status
- Two-factor authentication settings
- API token
- Profile picture
- Contact information
- Timezone and locale preferences
- Notification preferences
- Account creation date
- Created by (for audit)

## Business Context
Use these endpoints when:
- Onboarding new employees
- Managing user access and permissions
- Updating user roles or departments
- Deactivating departed employees
- Resetting passwords or credentials
- Auditing user activity
- Configuring team structures
- Managing API access
- Supporting user self-service
- Enforcing security policies
- Tracking system usage
- Generating user reports
- Integrating with HR systems
- Supporting compliance requirements

item.name: Warehouses

query.description: The number of warehouses to return per page. Defaults to 15.

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves a paginated list of all warehouses in the inventory management system. This endpoint returns warehouse locations with their basic information including names, addresses, operational status, and capacity details.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/warehouses`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
- **per_page** (integer, optional): Number of warehouses to return per page (default: 25, max: 100)
- **page** (integer, optional): Page number for pagination (default: 1)
- **search** (string, optional): Search term to filter warehouses by name, code, or address
- **status** (string, optional): Filter by operational status (active, inactive)
- **is_main** (boolean, optional): Filter to show only main warehouse (true) or secondary warehouses (false)

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for GET requests.

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing:
- **data**: Array of warehouse objects with:
  - Warehouse ID, name, and code
  - Address and location information
  - Operational status (active/inactive)
  - Main warehouse designation (is_main)
  - Capacity and current stock levels
  - Manager and contact information
  - Timestamps (created_at, updated_at)
- **meta**: Pagination metadata (current_page, total, per_page, last_page)
- **links**: Navigation links (first, last, prev, next)

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Warehouses retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view warehouses
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Invalid query parameters
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Display warehouse directory or listing page
- Populate warehouse selection dropdowns
- Search for specific warehouse locations
- Filter warehouses by operational status
- View all storage facilities in the system
- Generate warehouse reports
- Plan inventory distribution across locations

## Notes
- Results are paginated to optimize performance
- Use search parameter for quick warehouse lookup
- Main warehouse is typically the primary distribution center
- Inactive warehouses are included but can be filtered out
- Warehouse capacity helps plan inventory allocation
- Essential for multi-warehouse inventory management
- Consider caching results for frequently accessed lists

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Creates a new warehouse location in the inventory management system. This endpoint establishes a new storage facility with specified details including name, address, capacity, and operational settings.

## HTTP Method & URL
**POST** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/warehouses`

## Path Parameters
None

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
JSON object with warehouse details (required fields marked with *):
- **name*** (string): Warehouse name or location identifier
- **address*** (string): Physical address of the warehouse
- **description** (string, optional): Additional details about the warehouse purpose or characteristics
- **is_main** (boolean, optional): Designates if this is the main/primary warehouse (default: false)
- **code** (string, optional): Unique warehouse code or reference number
- **capacity** (integer, optional): Maximum storage capacity in units
- **manager_name** (string, optional): Name of warehouse manager
- **contact_phone** (string, optional): Contact phone number
- **contact_email** (string, optional): Contact email address
- **status** (string, optional): Operational status (default: active)

Example:
```json
{
  "name": "Secondary Warehouse",
  "address": "456 Storage Rd",
  "description": "Overflow storage.",
  "is_main": false
}
```

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing the newly created warehouse with:
- Assigned warehouse ID
- All provided warehouse details
- System-generated fields (code if not provided)
- Timestamps (created_at, updated_at)
- Success message

## Status Codes
- **201 Created** - Warehouse created successfully
- **200 OK** - Warehouse created with details returned
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to create warehouses
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors (missing required fields, duplicate code, invalid data)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Add new warehouse location to expand operations
- Set up regional distribution centers
- Create temporary storage facilities
- Establish main warehouse for new business
- Add overflow or seasonal storage locations
- Set up warehouse for specific product categories

## Notes
- Warehouse name should be descriptive and unique
- Only one warehouse can be designated as main warehouse
- Warehouse code must be unique if provided
- New warehouses start with zero inventory
- Consider setting up warehouse zones or sections after creation
- Capacity planning helps prevent overstocking
- Contact information is important for logistics coordination
- Status defaults to active for immediate use

## Endpoint Overview
Retrieves detailed information about a specific warehouse by its unique identifier. This endpoint returns comprehensive warehouse data including location, capacity, and current stock levels.

## HTTP Method & URL
**GET** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/warehouses/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the warehouse to retrieve

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for GET requests.

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing complete warehouse details:
- Warehouse ID, name, and code
- Location and address information
- Capacity and utilization metrics
- Manager and contact information
- Operational status
- Current stock summary
- Timestamps (created_at, updated_at)

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Warehouse retrieved successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to view warehouse details
- **404 Not Found** - Warehouse with specified ID does not exist
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Display warehouse details page
- Retrieve warehouse information for stock transfers
- Fetch warehouse data for editing
- View warehouse capacity and utilization
- Check warehouse operational status
- Access warehouse stock levels

## Notes
- Returns complete warehouse information including stock summary
- Use this endpoint when you need full warehouse details
- Warehouse capacity helps plan inventory distribution
- Stock levels reflect current inventory at this location
- Essential for multi-warehouse inventory management

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Updates an existing warehouse's information including name, address, description, and operational settings. This endpoint allows modification of warehouse details while preserving historical data and inventory associations.

## HTTP Method & URL
**PUT** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/warehouses/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the warehouse to update

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
JSON object with warehouse fields to update (all fields optional):
- **name** (string): Warehouse name or location identifier
- **address** (string): Physical address of the warehouse
- **description** (string): Additional details about the warehouse purpose or characteristics
- **is_main** (boolean): Designates if this is the main/primary warehouse
- **code** (string): Warehouse code or reference number
- **capacity** (integer): Maximum storage capacity
- **manager_name** (string): Name of warehouse manager
- **contact_phone** (string): Contact phone number
- **contact_email** (string): Contact email address
- **status** (string): Operational status (active, inactive)

Example:
```json
{
  "name": "Main Warehouse",
  "address": "123 Warehouse St",
  "description": "Primary storage facility.",
  "is_main": true
}
```

## Response Format
Returns a JSON object containing the updated warehouse details with all fields including:
- Updated warehouse information
- Confirmation message
- Timestamps showing last update

## Status Codes
- **200 OK** - Warehouse updated successfully
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to update warehouses
- **404 Not Found** - Warehouse with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Validation errors in request data
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Update warehouse address after relocation
- Change warehouse operational status
- Modify warehouse capacity information
- Update manager or contact details
- Change main warehouse designation
- Edit warehouse description or notes
- Update warehouse code or reference

## Notes
- Only provided fields will be updated; omitted fields remain unchanged
- Updating is_main to true may automatically set other warehouses to false
- Cannot update warehouse if it would create data inconsistencies
- Warehouse code must be unique across all warehouses
- Historical inventory transactions remain associated with the warehouse
- Consider impact on active stock transfers before major changes
- Deactivating a warehouse does not remove existing inventory

request.description:
## Endpoint Overview
Permanently removes a warehouse from the system. This endpoint deletes the specified warehouse and handles cleanup of associated records.

## HTTP Method & URL
**DELETE** `{{baseUrl}}/api/v1/warehouses/:id`

## Path Parameters
- **id** (integer, required): The unique identifier of the warehouse to delete

## Query Parameters
None

## Request Headers
- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for DELETE requests.

## Response Format
Returns a success message or empty response with appropriate status code.

## Status Codes
- **204 No Content** - Warehouse deleted successfully
- **200 OK** - Warehouse deleted with confirmation message
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to delete warehouses
- **404 Not Found** - Warehouse with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Cannot delete warehouse (has stock, active transfers, or associated transactions)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Remove closed or obsolete warehouse locations
- Delete duplicate warehouse entries
- Clean up test warehouses from production
- Consolidate warehouse operations

## Notes
- **IMPORTANT**: This operation is permanent and cannot be undone
- Warehouses with existing stock cannot be deleted
- Transfer or remove all inventory before deletion
- Warehouses with transaction history may be protected from deletion
- Consider deactivating warehouses instead of deleting to preserve historical data
- Deletion affects inventory tracking and historical records
- Ensure proper backup procedures before deletion
- Alternative: Mark warehouse as inactive rather than deleting

- **Content-Type**: `application/json` - Specifies JSON request format
- **Accept**: `application/json` - Expects JSON response
- **Authorization**: `Bearer {{access_token}}` - Required authentication token

## Request Body
Not applicable for DELETE requests.

## Response Format
Returns a success message or empty response with appropriate status code.

## Status Codes
- **204 No Content** - Warehouse deleted successfully
- **200 OK** - Warehouse deleted with confirmation message
- **401 Unauthorized** - Missing or invalid authentication token
- **403 Forbidden** - Insufficient permissions to delete warehouses
- **404 Not Found** - Warehouse with specified ID does not exist
- **422 Unprocessable Entity** - Cannot delete warehouse (has stock, active transfers, or associated transactions)
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server-side error occurred

## Usage Examples
- Remove closed or obsolete warehouse locations
- Delete duplicate warehouse entries
- Clean up test warehouses from production
- Consolidate warehouse operations

## Notes
- **IMPORTANT**: This operation is permanent and cannot be undone
- Warehouses with existing stock cannot be deleted
- Transfer or remove all inventory before deletion
- Warehouses with transaction history may be protected from deletion
- Consider deactivating warehouses instead of deleting to preserve historical data
- Deletion affects inventory tracking and historical records
- Ensure proper backup procedures before deletion
- Alternative: Mark warehouse as inactive rather than deleting

item.description:
## Overview
The Warehouses resource manages physical storage locations and inventory distribution centers in the Invent-MAG system. Warehouses represent facilities where products are stored, enabling multi-location inventory tracking and management.

## Purpose
Warehouses define storage locations for inventory, supporting businesses with multiple facilities, distribution centers, retail stores, or storage sites. This resource enables location-specific inventory tracking, inter-warehouse transfers, and optimized inventory distribution across the organization.

## Key Functionality
- Manage multiple warehouse locations
- Track inventory levels per warehouse
- Support warehouse hierarchies and zones
- Enable inter-warehouse transfers
- Configure warehouse-specific settings
- Track warehouse capacity and utilization
- Support location-based fulfillment
- Enable warehouse performance analytics
- Manage warehouse contact information
- Configure warehouse operating parameters

## Common Operations
- **GET /warehouses** - List all warehouses with details and inventory summaries
- **GET /warehouses/{id}** - Retrieve specific warehouse information and stock levels
- **POST /warehouses** - Create new warehouse locations
- **PUT/PATCH /warehouses/{id}** - Update warehouse details, settings, or status
- **DELETE /warehouses/{id}** - Remove warehouses (requires no inventory)

## Relationships
- **Products**: Stock levels maintained per warehouse
- **Stock Adjustments**: Inventory movements at specific warehouses
- **Sales Orders**: Orders fulfilled from specific warehouses
- **Purchase Orders**: Goods received into specific warehouses
- **Sales Items**: Products shipped from warehouses
- **Purchase Order Items**: Products received at warehouses
- **POS**: Point-of-sale locations linked to warehouses
- **Users**: Warehouse staff and managers

## Important Fields
- Warehouse name and code
- Warehouse type (distribution center, retail store, storage facility)
- Physical address and location
- Contact information (phone, email)
- Manager or responsible person
- Active/inactive status
- Capacity and size
- Operating hours
- Default warehouse flag
- Zones or sections
- Special handling capabilities
- Climate control specifications
- Security level

## Business Context
Use these endpoints when:
- Setting up multi-location inventory
- Opening new facilities or stores
- Managing inventory distribution
- Configuring fulfillment strategies
- Transferring stock between locations
- Analyzing warehouse performance
- Optimizing inventory placement
- Supporting retail operations
- Managing regional distribution
- Planning warehouse capacity
- Generating location-based reports
- Supporting logistics operations
- Integrating with shipping systems
- Managing warehouse costs and efficiency
